answers.answer: If your cardiologist does an angiogram and finds a significant blockage, a stent could be used to fix it. Although it is true that chances of needing a repeat procedure are higher in diabetics, the newer drug eluting stents have a lower rate of restenosis if adequate precautions and advice are followed.

question: My husband is 38 and has been a type 1 diabetic for 25 years.  He recently had a inconclusive EKG and Stress test for probable angina upon extertion.  He was sent for a thallium stress test which shows possible CAD with a blockage in one artery but apparently proper blood flow in the others (proper thallium uptake).  His EF is 50%.  It shows a small area at the bottom of the hear that indicates a prior MI that we were unaware of.  He is to see a cardiologist the end of March (best appointment available).  He is now on Diovan 160mg, a beta blocker 10mg, lipitor 80mg aspirin and a thyroid med. He has stopping drinking, is losing weight and we have changed diet to cut out red meats and reduce dietary cholesterol and salt.  Our family doctor feels that the cardiologist will do an angiogram and stenting.  I've read stenting isn't the best procedures for diabetics.My question is, it appears 50% EF is still normal.  Can this improve with stenting?Is stenting possible for him?Being diabetic, is he doomed to have this repeat regardless of the interventions we are taking?Can he stop this from getting worse by the measures he's taking.Thanks so much.
title: CAD and type 1 diabetes
